review.title: A weighted combination similarity measure for mobility patterns in wireless networks
review.abstract: The similarity between trajectory patterns in clustering has played an important role in discovering movement behaviour of different groups of mobile objects. Several approaches have been proposed to measure the similarity between sequences in trajectory data. Most of these measures are based on Euclidean space or on spatial network and some of them have been concerned with temporal aspect or ordering types. However, they are not appropriate to characteristics of spatiotemporal mobility patterns in wireless networks. In this paper, we propose a new similarity measure for mobility patterns in cellular space of wireless network. The framework for constructing our measure is composed of two phases as follows. First, we present formal definitions to capture mathematically two spatial and temporal similarity measures for mobility patterns. And then, we define the total similarity measure by means of a weighted combination of these similarities. The truth of the partial and total similarity measures are proved in mathematics. Furthermore, instead of the time interval or ordering, our work makes use of the timestamp at which two mobility patterns share the same cell. A case study is also described to give a comparison of the combination measure with other ones.

sections.heading: 2.1. Similarity Measures for Euclidean Space
sections.text: Measurements of similarity between Euclidean trajectory data and the referenced position of coordinates have been widely considered in various fields of research. Lin et al. [4] proposed a search method for similar trajectories by focusing on spatial shapes and comparing spatial shapes of moving object trajectories. Search algorithms based on the evaluation of OWD (disposable distance) in continuous and discrete cases of trajectories were developed. However, their search scheme OWD is time independent and based on Euclidean distance. Therefore, it is not appropriate to compare two trajectories in the cell space of wireless networks. Another method for measuring similarity between trajectories based on spatio-temporal representation was used by Zeinalipour-Yazti et al. sections.heading: 7. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: In this paper, we proposed a similarity measurement for spatio-temporal mobility patterns of wireless networks. We also presented the model of the mobility patterns of users in wireless networks that we developed and on which the similarity measurement is based. Our measurement variable related to characteristics represented in this model. We made mathematical measurements and then used a weighted combination to integrate these partial similarity measurements. The truth of this formulation was proven in mathematics. We also described a case study to compare our proposed measurement with the others. In our future work, we will develop a cluster algorithm of mobility patterns based on this similarity measurement and use this algorithm to construct a system to support predicting mobile users.
